newsitem.title: CHINA: China stocks end week up on improved sentiment.
newsitem.headline: China stocks end week up on improved sentiment.

text.p: China's A and B share indicies ended up on Friday on improved sentiment, with domestic investors the main buyers on the markets, brokers said.

Shanghai's B index edged up 0.17 points or 0.25 percent to 67.157 points on volume of 17.64 million worth $7.88 million. Brokers said rises on the A share market prompted increased buying by domestic investors on the B share market. The A index rose 16.018 points or 1.5 percent to 1,087.423 points.
"Domestic investors dominated recent market movements because they believe that most B share prices are better value than A shares," one broker said.

Another broker said he expected the index to move in a narrow range early next week as the market awaits the issue of annual reports. All listed companies are required to issue annual reports by April 30.
Tientsin Marine Shipping was the star on a technical rebound after sharp losses over the past few days, rising $0.024 or 5.42 percent to $0.466 on volume of 1.1 million shares.
Shanghai Haixin, the most active counter, followed, helped by talk of better 1996 results. It gained $0.022 or 4.7 percent to $0.490 on volume of 1.9 million shares.
Shanghai A shares reversed early losses on market expectations of an exchange announcement after the close, brokers said.
The Shanghai stock exchange issued a circular late in the afternoon ordering all brokerages to publicise each day's five most active stocks and the major traders starting next Monday.
A total of 628 million shares worth six billion yuan were traded. The SSE30 index rose 18.162 points or 0.65 percent to 2819.398 points.
Yanzhong Industry was the biggest gainer on speculative buying, surging 0.94 yuan or 10.04 percent to 10.3 yuan on volume of 9.5 million.

Shenzhen's B share index gained 1.4 points or 0.92 percent to 153.15 points on turnover of HK$87 million, supported by official reports that Shenzhen securities authorities and officials from major listed firms are stepping up efforts to promote B shares, brokers said.
"Market sentiment was improved by the news, which reflects the government's attitude towards the B share market," a broker said.
"This is certainly good news for the B share market," an analyst with a major Chinese brokerage said. "If successful, it will lead to an expanded base of B share investors."
Brokers said they expected the market to move slowly higher early next week, with buying focussing on companies expected to post good 1996 results.
China Bicycle was the best performer on institutional buying, rising HK$0.15 or 4.41 percent to HK$3.55 on heaviest trade of 2.03 million shares on institutional buying, brokers said.
The A share index firmed 3.06 points or 0.81 percent to close at 382.63 points on turnover of 9.54 billion yuan.
Brokers said they expected the gains to extend into next week.
Building materials producer Shenzhen Universe rose 0.79 yuan or 10 percent to close at limit-up of 8.65 yuan on speculative buying.
